content.title: Download Data
content: Several of the studies listed on the Discovery page provide datasets that may be downloaded for analysis. Users may download data files one at a time through the web or may use a transfer client to facilitate downloading many files or very large files. More information about downloading files is available here.

content.title: Repositories
content: The Gen3 Platform securely exposes data stored on multiple Gen3-approved repositories that are traditionally a part of a larger institution established for research, data archiving, and to serve data users of that organization. For more information, see here.

content.title: Access to Datasets
content: While many datasets on the Gen3 Platform are available for public use pending simple authentication, some datasets require further authorization to attain access. Please see here to learn more about gaining access to restricted datasets.

content.title: Analyze Data You Have Downloaded
content: The Gen3 Platform provides data that are organized, formatted and documented in a way to facilitate use of commonly used analytic software and techniques. The Platform also provides opportunities for you to share your results through the Platform, and can feature any publications arising from your analyses on the Publications Page. Click here to read more.

content.title: Browse Example Analyses
content: Browse under the “Example Analysis” tab for recent examples and tutorial analysis notebooks that leverage datasets on the Gen3 Platform in Python and R to learn how to analyze and visualize data or let them become the starting point of your own custom analysis. The notebooks are rendered in static html on the “Example Analyses” tab but can be also found in the workspaces in interactive mode. The list will be regularly updated with new and exciting tutorial data analysis notebooks, as more datasets are published and brought together in novel ways on the Gen3 Platform. Read further here.

content.title: Analyzing Data in a Workspace
content: The Gen3 platform offers a secure and cost-effective cloud-computing environment for analyzing data by yourself or together with others. Workspaces provide direct access to datasets, as well as common software tools including RStudio, Stata, and Python within a Jupyter Notebook interface.More information on workspaces is available here.

NIH-funded researchers may take advantage of the NIH Science and Technology Research Infrastructure for Discovery, Experimentation, and Sustainability (STRIDES) credit. Click here to request NIH STRIDES credit for the use of our workspaces.

content.title: Share Your Results
content: Researchers analyzing data obtained through the Gen3 Platform are encouraged to share their results with the community so others may learn from and build on what they have done. Share notebooks you create in a workspace automatically with researchers around the globe using GitHub.

content.title: Look for Data by State
content: Policies and state laws are key to maximize the benefits of new implementations from public health departments addressing the opioid crisis and thus have a significant impact on the lives of those struggling with chronic pain or substance use disorders. As an example, the prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) is an electronic database that tracks controlled substance prescriptions in a state to improve opioid prescribing, inform clinical practice, and protect patients at risk. Such implementations will be most effective if states effectuate policies that require providers to a state PDMP prior to prescribing certain controlled substances. The Gen3 Platform shares research about new and innovative implementations and other useful datasets that inform evidence-based decisions on state policies. Click here to find datasets that may inform policy updates by filtering datasets by U.S. state.

content.title: New Data
content: The Gen3 Platform frequently shares new and state-of-the-art research regarding treatment, prevention, intervention, overdose, recovery, and criminal justice populations. New data will help advance laws and policies to support public health and safety measures, which ultimately leads to more education, stigma reduction, more safety net measures, and one step closer mitigating the public health crisis around opioid addiction and chronic pain. Discover the latest policy-related datasets here.
